IT IS A PLEASURE TO WELCOME
YOU to TWA. The material in this
packet is planned to help make your
journey more pleasant, and to tell
you a little more about TWA.
YOU MAY TAKE THIS PACKET WITH
YOU with the compliments of The
Transcontinental Airline if you wish
more time to study the contents or
desire a souvenir of your journey.
SHORTEST. FASTEST
COAST-TO-COAST

Map and Log
(TWA
TRANSCONTINENTAL
Airline

Border segments represent 20 miles. Airways are fully lighted by revolving beacons.
Strip Map Number
Highways
Railroads
Rivers, streams, lakes, ponds
AIR MAPS ARE LIKE ROAD MAPS
Mar expert caparatin with TeA mailion Ded arment,
in every detail. Points of interest can be easily identified, help-
ing passengers orient themselves and pass the time pleasantly.
We hope you, as TWA's guest, will enjoy this presentation of
the nation's shortest, fastest coast-to-coast air route. If you wish,
you may keep this air map and log as a souvenir of your trip.
YEAR 'ROUND FLYING-OVER AND AROUND THE WEATHER
Unfavorable weather conditions are generally local in
the weather-that is, above surface weather disturb-
character. To detour most weather disturbances-fly
ances. Supercharged cabins enable Stratoliners to fly
around the weather-the Government has given TWA
at altitudes up to 20,000 feet, from 8,000 to 16,000
permission to fly various alternate routes. With these
feet, the "altitude" inside the cabin remains at a con-
facilities, there are very few days when it is impossible
stant 8,000 feet; from 16,000 to 20,000 feet the in-
to complete flights on either TWA's main route or its
ternal cabin "altitude"
gradually increases to 12,000
optional routes. In addition to this possibility, TWA's
feet, assuring passengers comfort and overweather
great 4-engine Stratoliners are capable of flying over
smoothness in flight.
THINGS TO KNOW ABOUT FLYING
SERVICE ALOFT... Your TWA hostess is anxious to
supply any information you wish, and to assist in making
your trip comfortable and enjoyable. Consult your copy
of the service booklets carried on board, and request any
of the available facilities from your hostess.
ENGINE SOUND ... During the course of each flight,
changes in the sound and "beat" of the motors may be
noticed. This is caused by the normal changing of the
variable pitch propellers for different rates of climb, level
flight and descent controlled by the captain.
IT'S GOOD FORM TO YAWN... Descending from high
altitudes may create an ear sensation similar to that ex-
perienced in an elevator. In TWA's Stratoliners, this may
occur, but only during the brief period of take-off or
landing when the cabin super-charger is not in operation.
But to relieve the sensation during this period, chew
the
gum supplied by your hostess and swallow often.
Or, better yet, just open your mouth and yawn!
RETURN TRIP RESERVATIONS... To avoid the possibility
of all seats being sold on the day you wish to return, your
return reservations should be made as soon as possible
after arrival at destination, or preferably before com-
mencing your journey. Round trip tickets purchased in
advance carry a 10% discount.

(TWA
TRANSCONTINENTAL

observe curtain rules
-In the interest of our
war effort, we urge your co-operation with Government
regulations regarding your plane window curtains. Curtains
are to be kept closed while the plane is on the ground, just
before landing, after take-off,
and at certain infrequent
times in flight. Observance of this regulation at ALL times,
by ALL passengers will be greatly appreciated.

resident Roosevelt's his-
tory-making flight to Africa
added a new page to the
spectacular story of Avia-
tion. We believe you will be
interested in this reprint of
a TWA message which ap-
peared in metropolitan
newspapers, calling
atten-
tion to the signal importance
of this memorable journey.

TRANSENA
-- The TRANSCONTINENTAL Arline
- ThE TRANSCONTINENTAL Airline

For
Your Guidance
A recent statement by the Civil Aeronautics
Board clarifies the position of the airlines in
the Nation's War Effort. There has been con-
fusion on this subject, hence the CAB state-
ment released on May 22, 1942, is laid out
below for your information and guidance.
Status of the Airlines
"The recent announcement by the War Depart-
ment made in connection with the President's
directive for a further coordination and integra-
tion of domestic air transportation with the activ-
ties of the military service, illustrates the truth
expressed by the President on January 24, 1939,
when he asserted that:
" "The country's welfare in time of peace and
its safety in time of wer rests upon * * * an
economically and technically sound air transporta-
tion system?
"The President's recent directive contemplates
the transfer of a substential portion of the avail-
eble flight equipment to Army air forces to be
operated by the various services and commands of

the Army; the conversion of a substantial number
of ships into cargo carriers to be operated by air-
line personnel under contract for the Air Service
Command; and the use of the remainder of the
equipment (about one-half of the present supply
of the domestic lines) by the airlines in the con-
tinuance of their regular scheduled operations;
subject to their availability for military missions in
emergencies. Routes and schedules in airline oper-
ation which are not regarded as essential to the
war effort will be terminated to make possible the
bighest utilization of the reduced equipment which
is available to the airlines. Air travel vital to the
country's needs will continue, subject to the
enforcement of a strict system of priorities.
Availability of Service
"The facts as stated make clear the error in
the press reports of the last few days which
announced that operation of the airlines had
been taken over by the War Department. While
the scheduled airline services have been limited pri-
marily to the war purposes and arrangements have
been made for a closer adaptation of those services
to the war needs, and while the number of schedules
have been substantially curtailed and in some in-
stances routes suspended the airlines will continue
to render service under their certificates of
public convenience and necessity and in accord-
ance with the regulatory authority of the Civil
Aeronautics Act.
The whole-hearted fashion
in which the air carriers have cooperated witb
the military services in furtherance of the war
effort has made it possible for them to continue
operating under private management even
though they now constitute essentially an arm
of the national defense.
"Thus, the CAB and its staff are assured that
their work has become tied in more closely than
ever before with the war effort. They have already
taken an active and major part in close cooperation
with the Military Director of Civil Aviation, in
the development and the plans for putting into
early effect the President's directive, and will con-
tinue to discharge those regulatory functions pre-
scribed by the Civil Aeronautics Act which are
even more necessary in war than in peace." (Note—
the captions and bold italics are our own.)
Please note the following:
1. The airlines continue to operate regu-
lar schedules with equipment not
transferred to the Army.
2. Air travel vital to the country's needs
will continue, subject to the enforce-
ment of priorities.
3. The airlines continue their operation
as such and have not been taken over
by the War Department.
While the airlines "now constitute essen-
tially an arm of the national defense," and
schedules have been set up to serve essential
traffic flow, space available will be reserved
on request subject to priority of national de-
fense traffic
movement. We suggest your
continuing to call
our reservations depart-
ment who will be happy to keep you accurately
advised
concerning availability of space on
our schedules to all points.

Priority regulations provide for the estab-
lishment of priority rating for essential civilian
travel by air. Where individuals and firms
are directly engaged in the war effort they
smay be entitled to such rating. Any of our
offices will, on request, direct you to the
proper official channels for determination of
your priority status.
(TWA
TRANSCONTINENTAL
Airline
TRANSCONTINENTAL & WESTERN AIR, Inc.

Vacant Seats on a "Sold Out" Plane?
TWA
TRANSCONTINENTAL
Airline

Three Reasons for Vacant Seals
When you discover empty seats on a TWA plane that has been reported "sold out,"
it can be for any of the following reasons:
"no-show"
passengers
Travelers who have reserved space
sometimes change their plans with
out cancelling their reservations. Consequently,
the space they have reserved cannot be released
for sale and the plane departs with empty
seats.
This failure of
no-show
passengers to call-
cel reservations presents a problem-particu-
larly right now when airline capacity is being
utilized to the limit by thousands on missions
concerned with the nation's war effort.
The "no-show"
passenger is not only being
unfair to the airlines and the public but by
depriving another passenger of a seat, he may
be hampering the wartime program of the na-
tion as well. Always make it a pomt to cancel
reservanons ipe minure
you hind you can't
utilize the space you control.
air mail
Airlines carrying U. S. mail, do so
under contract with the govern-
ment. The volume of this mail often varies.
But whatever the quantity, the mail must go
through. Although stowed in a special com-
partment, the weight of air mail must, never-
theless, be considered in planning the flight.
This means that. on occasions when the mail
is exceptionally heavy, it may be necessary to
operate with some empty seats.
3
our reserve fuel supply
The third and tar-more-common
reason for empty seats on a "sold
out plane is simply this: The ticket-value of
those seats has been sacrificed so that the plane
can carry extra fuel.
Just to make this clear, here are some basic
figures in simple Airplane Arithmetic:
rassenger.
plus baggage, averages
210 pounds.
Gallon of gasoline weighs 6
pounds.
Therefore, for each seat left empty, the plane
can take on 35 gallons of additional fuel. And

• The TRANSCONTINENTAL Airline
SHORTEST, FASTEST, COAST-TO-COAST

WHAT HAS
BECOME OF THE
Stratoliners?
ENTAL
Lime
Stratoliner
NOW SERVING THE NATION IN OVER-OCEAN
FLYING FOR THE AIR TRANSPORT COMMAND
STRATOLINER MAKES 17 OCEAN CROSSINGS IN 22 DAYS
For more than a year TWA Stratoliners in Army camouflage have
been roaming the airways of the world, serving urgent air trans-
port needs of our country's armed forces abroad.
Famous cities in foreign lands have become familiar ports of call
for the big four-engine airliners that introduced faster, high-level
luxury flying to air travelers in the United States.
Carrying irreplaceable war cargo to rough, hurriedly-made air-
ports, the Stratoliners have each flown thousands of miles a week,
often with loads tons greater than they were designed to carry.
One of the Stratoliners recently made a record of seventeen
ocean crossings in only twenty-two days in delivering critically
needed materials to our fighting men overseas.
The record-breaking peacetime performance of the Stratoliners,
when they carried 110,000 passengers in 19 months, has been
more than equalled by their wartime service to the nation.
TWA Services Performed for the Armed Forces: Over-Ocean Air
Transport Operations — Military Aircraft Modification - Army
Aircraft Mechanic, Radio Operator and Radio Mechanic Train-
ing
Four-Engine Flight Crew Training
Communications
Engineering — North American Air Cargo Service.
Government support has been given the airlines in part to prepare them
to serve the needs of National Defense. This is another in a series of mes
sages telling how TWA is fulfilling its obligations to the nation in wartime.
TRANSCONTINENTAL & WESTERN AIR, INC.
The
TWA
TRANSCONTINENTAL
Airline

2001.015.02

elts a Way We Have
in the

elts a Way We Have in the U.S.A.
Just as America's spiritual
greatness is founded on individual
freedom, so is our material greatness founded
on our unique system of free enterprise.
In this country we have demonstrated that
free competition in industry can produce
the highest standard of living and the great-
est concentration of
material
resources
known to the world.
But in times like these normal competition
quickly gives way to complete co-operation.
When our cherished way of life is threatened
our great industries pool their vast resources
and their vital supply of skilled man-power
to accomplish more quickly the tasks for
which they are peculiarly fitted.
This is a way we have in the U.S. A.—a way
that is both confusing and demoralizing to
our enemies.
Today the many commercial airlines, nor-
mally competitive, are working together on
the vital task of speeding our war effort. To
this common purpose the air transportation
industry is devoting its entire resources in
materials and men.
Transcontinental e Western Air, Inc.
TWA
TRANSCONTINENTAL
Airline
